Award.AwardTitle: Standardized Performance Testing of Multispectral Reflectance Oximetry Imaging (MROI) in Emerging Device Platforms

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will develop advanced methods for characterizing minimally-invasive diagnostic medical devices. The research will facilitate the development and standardized performance testing of novel biophotonic technologies for early disease detection and image-guided surgery.

3D-printed biomimetic phantoms for the performance testing of near-infrared spectroscopy systems (NIRS) will be developed and the PI will investigate near-infra-red (IR) fluorescence (NIRF) image quality through phantom-based measurements to explore the basis for developing standards that can be used to validate NIRF imaging systems. The development of novel biomimetic phantoms for noninvasive fluorescence molecular imaging (FMI) will elucidate optimal fabrication approaches that influence the effectiveness of 3D-printed phantoms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multispectral reflectance oximetry imaging (MROI) imaging has been well developed, characterized, and deployed commercially over the last twenty years. This technology is used for noninvasive assessment of hemoglobin saturation and concentration – and thus tissue perfusion and viability – in patients with potential circulatory compromise, such as diabetic patients, or during surgeries involving skin flaps. It has also been extensively studied for assessment of retinal vasculature. Recently, there are increasing efforts to translate MROI technology onto a mobile-phone platform for point-of-care diagnostics and telemedicine.

 

In this study, we have developed and evaluated multi-channel phantoms with injectable Hb solutions. We fabricated multi-channel phantoms incorporating basic and biomimetic designs using 3D printing approaches, and investigated the use of sodium dithionite to control the saturation. We carried out image quality characterization using a scientific CCD and NIR-enabled mobile phones to show the capabilities of mobile-phone-based MROI imaging. The phones showed performance comparable to a scientific CCD.

 

In addition, we investigated a novel 3D printing method, two-photon direct laser printing (Nanoscribe). Using this method, we demonstrated that hollow microvascular tissue phantoms of the retina vasculature can be fabricated at a biomimetic scale of 10-μm diameter. We printed the retina phantoms inside an “organ-on-a-chip” device, and imaged using microscope. Our result shows that blood can be injected into the hollow channels for retinal oximetry.

 


Last Modified: 02/11/2020
Modified by: Yu Chen
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Multispectral reflectance oximetry imaging (MROI) imaging has been well developed, characterized, and deployed commercially over the last twenty years. This technology is used for noninvasive assessment of hemoglobin saturation and concentration – and thus tissue perfusion and viability – in patients with potential circulatory compromise, such as diabetic patients, or during surgeries involving skin flaps. It has also been extensively studied for assessment of retinal vasculature. Recently, there are increasing efforts to translate MROI technology onto a mobile-phone platform for point-of-care diagnostics and telemedicine. In this study, we have developed and evaluated multi-channel phantoms with injectable Hb solutions. We fabricated multi-channel phantoms incorporating basic and biomimetic designs using 3D printing approaches, and investigated the use of sodium dithionite to control the saturation. We carried out image quality characterization using a scientific CCD and NIR-enabled mobile phones to show the capabilities of mobile-phone-based MROI imaging. The phones showed performance comparable to a scientific CCD. In addition, we investigated a novel 3D printing method, two-photon direct laser printing (Nanoscribe). Using this method, we demonstrated that hollow microvascular tissue phantoms of the retina vasculature can be fabricated at a biomimetic scale of 10-μm diameter. We printed the retina phantoms inside an "organ-on-a-chip" device, and imaged using microscope. Our result shows that blood can be injected into the hollow channels for retinal oximetry.
